loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy traditional baskets (Ciondos)

loans.name: Valeh

texts.en:
Valeh has bred cattle for 6 years. He is 28 years old and single. This young man lives in Salyan region, Khaladj village.

He is applying for a loan of $1200 to buy 2 pregnant cows to increase the number of his cows and get more income for cover all his expenses.

loans.use: To buy 2 pregnant cows

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To add stock of indigenous foods

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Teresia would like to buy clothing and materials to make dresses to sell in her shop.

loans.name: Anna

texts.en: Anna is a motivated young entrepreneur from Melitopol, Ukraine. With help from her parents, she started a small business about two years ago selling women’s shoes and clothing from a small space at one of the busy markets in Melitopol. She is serious and goal-oriented when it comes to business. Though she has been self-employed for a relatively short period of time, her business has done well. She currently makes around $1,400 per month. Anna has requested a loan of $1,000 that will help her increase her available inventory and continue building her business.

loans.use: Increase inventory

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Agnes would like to buy a dairy cow

loans.name: Yelena

texts.en: Yelena sells attractive leather purses from a little space at the busy Rushski Market in Melitopol, Ukraine. A good location in the market helps boost her sales and has contributed to the success of her business. Financial assistance from Nadiya Ukraine has also been instrumental in helping her through the years she has been in business. She has been a great client, repaying each loan she has received with no delays. Yelena enjoys selling purses and with two daughters, the business is a neat fit for her family, as well. Yelena has requested a loan of $450 to help her purchase additional inventory for her business.

loans.use: Increase inventory

loans.name: Lubov

texts.en: Lubov is an experienced entrepreneur, having had her own business for thirteen years. She currently has a small kiosk where she sells children’s clothing and door lock sets. Lubov is divorced and has raised her nineteen-year-old son almost entirely by herself. Her business has been a vital source of funds for them to live on. After graduating from college, her son had difficulty finding a job so she helped support him financially. Aside from meeting her own basic needs, Lubov would like to see her business provide the means to help her son get established in life. She has requested a loan of $200 to purchase some seasonal children’s clothing. She hopes that the summer time will be profitable for her business and it will bring in necessary income.

loans.use: Increase inventory

loans.name: Sergei

texts.en: Sergei is a divorced father and is raising his fifteen-year-old daughter, Anna, on his own. He started his business selling children’s shoes and house shoes eight years ago at a time when he was going through some financial difficulty. The house shoes he sells are popular in Ukraine. It is customary for everyone to leave their shoes at the door when entering a home. House shoes or slippers are used when indoors and many times extra pairs are offered to visiting guests. Sergei tries to maintain a variety of available shoes at his kiosk for customers to choose from. He has requested a loan of $300 to purchase new inventory so he will have a supply of shoes on hand to meet demand.

loans.use: Increase inventory

loans.name: Tatyana

texts.en: Tatyana enjoys what she does for a living. She has her own little business selling women’s clothing at the Rushski Market in Melitopol, Ukraine. Married and the mother of two, she has been in business for about nine years. Her business has been a valuable source of income through the years. Tatyana has been helping her youngest child with his college expenses and also helps her parents when she can. Her husband recently retired as a school teacher, but Tatyana plans to keep working and developing her enterprise. She has requested a loan for $1,000 to increase the assortment of clothing she has available to sell.

loans.use: Increase inventory

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Consolata would like to buy cloth materials.

loans.name: Basilia

texts.en:
Basilia L. M., here pictured in front of the church where her group Bank of Hope meets, owns a general store in the community of Juan Pablo Duarte, named for the founding father of the Dominican Republic. Basilia sells food products like rice and sugar in her store to help her husband Carlos support their three children: Harold (19), Carmen (17), and Macien (16). All three children are in school and Harold has started work in a nearby town. Carmen will probably start work soon, but she aspires to be an architect, though Basilia worries about being able to pay for schooling. This loan will help Basilia expand her stock of goods in order to grow her small business.

Note: Basilia is one of five microentrepreneurs in her Bank of Hope solidarity group, all of whom have gone through Esperanza's business training courses. Each of the five members will receive a share of this $1125 loan for their respective businesses and will be accountable to each other for repaying their share of this loan together. This group-lending method strengthens social needs in the community and helps ensure that members cooperate to help one another repay their loans and invest wisely in their businesses and families.

loans.use: Business expansion, augment stock of goods

loans.name: Mariana

texts.en:
Mariana J. S. owns a general store in Magdalena, a community in the Dominican Republic with strong cultural ties to Haiti. Mariana, like most of Magdalena's residents, is of Haitian ancestry; her family immigrated several generations ago in hope of a better future. Mariana sells bread, canned fish, candy, and other edibles; she will use this loan to expand the offerings of her store. Mariana is divorced with three children: Milagro Garcia (28), Jenifer (22), and Yerba (7). She hopes that the further success of her business will allow her to someday buy her own house in Magdalena; she currently lives with relatives.

Note: Mariana is one of five microentrepreneurs in her Bank of Hope solidarity group, all of whom have gone through Esperanza's business training courses. Each of the five members will receive a share of this $800 loan for their respective businesses and will be accountable to each other for repaying their share of this loan together. This group-lending method strengthens social needs in the community and helps ensure that members cooperate to help one another repay their loans and invest wisely in their businesses and families.

loans.use: Store stock expansion

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Equipment for business expansion

loans.name: Cornelio

texts.es:
Cornelio is 40 years old, has been married for 4 years and has three children, all of which are minors and still in school. His wife, Justina, is a housewife and helps him earn money working in their store.

Cornelio and his wife used to live with his parents in Carapeguá and hoped to one day have a home of their own. They thus went on a trip to Argentina to work and earn enough money to build a house.

About four years ago they returned and built their house. They also set up their store, which Justina managed while Cornelio started another business in order to double their income. He started to work as a traveling salesman selling typical local products like blankets, hammocks, hand-embroidered table cloths, etc.

Since they are both very enterprising and hard-working, their businesses soon grew. Cornelio used the earnings generated by the businesses to buy a motorcycle that he uses in his work as a traveling salesman.

Cornelio hopes to continue this expansion by increasing the stock of merchandise for his traveling sales. For this purpose he is asking for a loan of $600, which he will invest in his business to buy more blankets, embroidered tablecloths, bedspreads, hammocks and typical local shirts. This will enable him to increase his income to continue to give his family a good life and will allow his children to continue to study so that they can become professionals.

Translated from Spanish by Alexandra Jaffe, Kiva volunteer.

El Señor Cornelio tiene 40 años, está casado hace 4 años, tiene tres hijos, todos ellos menores y están en edad escolar. Su señora Justina es ama de casa y lo ayuda con los ingresos de la casa, atendiendo un almacén que tienen ambos.

Cornelio y su señora vivían anteriormente con sus padres en unas de las compañías de la ciudad de Carapeguá, con el sueño de tener una vivienda propia decidieron emprender un viaje a la República Argentina con su señora para trabajar y así juntar la plata para construir la casa.

Hace cuatro años atrás volvieron y construyeron su casa, donde también montaron su despensa, que es administrado por Justina, mientras que Cornelio emprendió a la par otra actividad para poder doblar sus ingresos, el se dedica a la venta ambulante productos típicos de la zona, como ser frazadas, hamacas, manteles bordados a mano, etc. Como ambos son personas muy emprendedoras y trabajadoras, en poco tiempo ellos fueron progresando; con las ganancias generadas, Cornelio compró uno motocicleta que lo utiliza para sus ventas ambulantes.

Cornelio está deseoso de seguir progresando, desea aumentar su stock de mercaderías para la venta ambulante por lo que solicita un crédito de $ 600 que los invertirá en la compra de más frazadas, manteles bordados, cobertores, hamacas, y camisas típicas, esto permitirá aumentar sus ingresos para seguir dando a su familia una vida digna y lograr que sus hijos sigan estudiando para que el día de mañana sean profesionales de bien.

loans.use: To purchase blankets, embroidered table cloths, bedspreads, hammocks and typical local shirts

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buy more fish and kerosene to sell

loans.name: Deolinda

texts.es:
Deolinda is 39 years old, has been married for 20 years and has three children, all minors and still in school. Her husband has been the chauffer of a locally well-known businessman for three years and used to be a traveling salesman.

While her husband was a traveling salesman, Deolinda was a housewife but wanted to contribute to the household. After her children were born she saved some money and invested in a little kiosk in their neighborhood (a residential area in Carapeguá) because there wasn’t a store that sold staple products. Today her business is one of the biggest stores in the neighborhood and most people living in the area buy their products from her because her store offers all staple products and other various products.

She started to work with Fundación Paraguaya a few years ago and joined a women’s group of microbusinesses in her neighborhood call “Kuña Guapa” (fighting woman). In the group there are 15 members that work together to make weekly payments towards their loans. They are jointly responsible for all of their loans.

Today Deolinda hopes to further expand her microbusiness and is asking for a loan of $150 that she will use to purchase wholesale products like pasta, sugar and dairy products.

Translated from Spanish by Alexandra Jaffe, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Deolinda tiene 39 años, está casada hace 20 años, tiene tres hijos, todos ellos menores y están en edad escolar, su marido es chofer particular de un conocido empresario de la zona hace tres años, anteriormente el señor se dedicaba a las ventas ambulantes.

Mientras su marido se dedicaba a las ventas ambulantes, la señora era sólo ama de casa, pero ella quería aportar con los ingresos de la casa y como nacieron también sus hijos, ella junto unos ahorros y los invirtió en la instalación de un pequeño kiosco, ya que en el lugar donde están (zona de viviendas populares de Carapeguá) faltaba un negocio de donde se pueda comprar los productos de primera necesidad. Hoy en día es una de las Despensas más grandes del barrio, y de ahí se surten casi todos los habitantes del vecindario, ya que ofrece todos los productos de primera necesidad y otros productos varios.

Ella empezó a trabajar con la Fundación Paraguaya hace un año atrás, asociándose a un Comité de Mujeres que se formó en su barrio, el grupo de microempresas se llama “Kuñá Guapa” (mujer luchadora), conforman el grupo 15 socias, trabajan todas juntas, pagan semanalmente por los préstamos adquiridos y la responsabilidad del crédito es solidaria.

Hoy día Deolinda está deseosa de seguir viendo progresar su microempresas, por lo que solicita un crédito de $ 150 que lo invertirá en la compra de productos para la venta al por mayor como fideo, azúcar y lácteos.

loans.use: to buy wholesale pasta, sugar and dairy products.

loans.name: Blásida

texts.es:
Blásida is 50 years old, has been married for 20 years and has a 22 year-old daughter who is a student. Her husband is a farmer.

While her husband worked as a farmer, Blásida worked part-time as a secretary in the Paz courts but since the pay wasn’t very good, she started to embroider tablecloths and sell bedspreads to help her husband with the household income. Her daughter then became ill and had to undergo a lengthy treatment and Blásida, motivated by the hope to overcome the difficulty and by the desperation to save her daughter, looked for another way to earn more money. She bought milk cows and started to sell milk and cheese.

Since her father-in-law had a field that he didn’t use, she decided to work the land cultivating various products like cassava, corn, tomatoes and other vegetables that she sold at the market. Blásida is now a woman of many trades, worthy of admiration; thanks to her tenacity her daughter is now cured and Blásida is also able to use her income to pay for her daughter’s studies. Blásida main goal is to ensure that her daughter finishes her studies and becomes a professional. She is admired by her neighbors for her tireless work and her dedication to her family.

Today Blásida is hoping to start a new project, this time to start a microbusiness so that her daughter can work and earn her own money; for this she is asking for a loan of $800 that she will use to buy clothes to sell like T-shirts, jackets, pants and shirts.

Translated from Spanish by Alexandra Jaffe, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Blásida tiene 50 años, está casada hace 20 años, tiene una hija, ella tiene 22 años es estudiante, su marido es agricultor.

Mientras su marido se dedicaba a la agricultura, Blásida trabajaba medio tiempo como secretaria en el Juzgado de Paz pero como el salario no era bueno, empezó a bordar manteles y vender sobrecamas para ayudar a su marido con los ingresos de la casa, tiempo después su única hija enfermó y debía seguir un tratamiento largo, Blásida, impulsada por el deseo de superación y desesperación por salvar a su hija busco una actividad más para generar más ingresos y compro dos vacas lecheras y empezó la venta de leche y queso.

Como su suegro tiene un campo al que no le daba uso, ella decidió trabajar la tierra sembrando varios productos como ser mandioca, ,maíz, tomate y otras hortalizas que los comercializa en el mercado, Hoy día Blásida es una mujer multifacética, digna de admiración; con sus ingresos logra pagar los estudios de su hija que gracias a su tenacidad hoy está curada, ella nos cuenta que su mayor objetivo es lograr que su hija culmine sus estudios y sea una profesional. Es muy admirada por sus vecinos por su incansable trabajo y dedicación a su familia.

Hoy está en miras de un nuevo emprendimiento, esta vez desea iniciar una microempresa para que su hija pueda trabajar y ganar su propio dinero; para ello solicita un crédito $ 800 que lo utilizará para la compra de ropas para vender, como remeras, camperas, pantalones y camisas.

loans.use: To buy clothing to sell like T-shirts, jackets, pants and shirts.

loans.name: Angelica

texts.es:
ANGELICA is 21 years old, married, and has one son. Her husband works as a baker. She sells chicken from her house to her neighbors. She forms part of the group "Aries 1" along with doña Candelaria Díaz Pérez (who has a grocery store). With the loan Angélica will support her husband's bakery and also improve her business while doña Candelaria will increase her store's supply by purchasing more food products.

Translated from Spanish by Jay Osborne, Kiva volunteer

ANGELICA, tiene 21 años, casada, 1 hijo su esposo trabaja como panadero, ella vende pollos trozados en su casa a la gente que vive cerca de su domicilio Forma parte del grupo Aries 1 junto con doña Candelaria Díaz Pérez (tienda de abarrotes).Con el préstamo Angélica apoyara a su esposo en el negocio de la panadería y también incrementará su negocio y doña Candelaria abastecerá su tienda comprando productos comestibles.

loans.use: Selling chicken

loans.name: Amarilis

texts.en:
Amarilis P. F., 43, makes beautiful paper wreaths for funerals and for All Saints' Day. She makes them to order and also sells in her father's casket shop. The three-foot-diameter wreaths come in whole array of colors. She can make up to a dozen in a day and sells as many as four dozen a month for a profit of 300-400 Quetzals (US$40-$50). With this credit she will buy the materials for her products: paper, paint, and the plastic packaging. At some point she wants to expand into making papier mache piñatas and candles, but the materials for those are more expensive.

Amarilis is married and has three children, all in school. She's thankful that all are in good health. She's a member of the group of women "Barrio Llovizna" and is on her third loan.

loans.use: Purchase paper, paint, plastic packaging for artificial funeral flower wreaths

loans.name: Lupita

texts.es:
LUPITA is 22 years old, married, and has one son. Her husband works as a technician for a company called "Empresa de Cable Visión". She has a grocery store in her home and is a member of the group Aries 1. The other member is Julia Álvarez Díaz (who has bread-making business). WIth the loan Lupita will buy merchandise for her store and Julia will buy cooking instruments and primary ingredients for increasing her production of bread.

Translated from Spanish by Jay Osborne, Kiva volunteer

LUPITA, tiene 22 años, casada con 1 hijo, su esposo trabaja como técnico en una Empresa de Cable Visión. Ella tiene una tienda de abarrotes en su casa, forma parte del grupo Aries 1. Las otras integrantes son: Julia Álvarez Díaz (tiene una amasandería). Con el préstamo Lupita comprará mercadería para su tienda y Julia comprará implementos de cocina y materia prima para aumentar la producción de pan

loans.use: Purchasing merchandise for grocery store

loans.name: Esther

texts.es:
ESTER is 25 years old, married, and has one son. Her husband is dedicated to renting movies. She has a little business in her home where she sells clothes and linens. WIth the loan she hopes to increase her merchandise and begin selling from house to house in her community. She is a member of the group "Aries 2" along with doña Hermelinda Encina Pérez (who sells bread from house to house), doña Julia Gómez Álvarez (who sells clothes), and Ángela López Pérez (who makes crafts with amber). With the loan they hope to invest in their businesses by acquiring more merchandise and increasing sales.

Translated from Spanish by Jay Osborne, Kiva volunteer

ESTER, tiene 25 años, casada, 1 hijo, su esposo se dedica a la renta de películas. Ella tiene en su casa un pequeño negocio en donde vende ropa y lencería, con el préstamo espera aumentar su mercadería y comenzar a vender casa por casa en su comunidad. Pertenece al grupo Aries 2 junto con doña Hermelinda Encina Pérez (venta de pan casa por casa) y doña Julia Gómez Álvarez (vende ropa) y Ángela López Pérez (artesanía en ámbar). Con el préstamo esperan invertir en sus negocios aumentando las ventas al adquirir más mercancía.

loans.use: Selling clothes and linens

loans.name: Ana Leticia

texts.en:
Ana Leticia J., 19, who lived in San Felipe, has a tiny food and convenience store where she sells sugar, tamales, fruit, potatoes, and beans. The little store has been operating for seven years, but only in the last year (using Friendship Bridge credit) did they acquire a refrigerator so they can offer cold drinks. The refrigerator is now paid off completely.

Ana Leticia is on her 5th loan, having grown her credit to where she can ask for 2500 Guatemalan Quetzals, which will be used for inventory for the store. Eventually she hopes to open a larger store. It is her hope to prosper so that she can provide for her two children. Her group of women is called "Barrio La Llovizna".

During this time of year (the rainy season) the children are particularly susceptible to illness, especially diarrhea, so there are more expenses for medical care and more fear for the children's health. One of Ana Leticia's hopes is to have enough resources to cover the family's health needs during this season.

loans.use: Inventory for Ana Leticia's food store

loans.name: Pascuala

texts.es:
PASCUALA is 45 years old, a widow, and has five children. She is dedicated to raising and fattening pigs. With the loan she will buy food and medicine to protect her animals. She sells them among the people of her community; sometimes they are sold alive or ready for consumption. She is a member of the group "Puente (Bridge) 1" along with doña Leonor de la Cruz Gómez (who is a seamstress) y doña Julia Díaz Hernández (who sells pastries). The two hope to invest the loan by buying Leonor more fabric to make more clothing and Julia more flour and sugar to make more pastries.

Translated from Spanish by Jay Osborne, Kiva volunteer

PASCUALA tiene 45 años, viuda, cinco hijos. Ella se dedica a la crianza y engorda de puercos, con el préstamo comprara alimento y medicamentos para proteger a sus animales, y los vende entre la gente de su comunidad algunas veces vivos y otras para consumo. Pertenece al grupo Puente 1 junto con doña Leonor de la Cruz Gómez (costurera) y doña Julia Díaz Hernández (venta de pasteles). Ellas dos esperan invertir comprando Leonor mas tela para confeccionar mas prendas y Julia comprara harina y dulces para elaborar pastelitos.

loans.use: Raising and selling pigs

loans.name: Víctor Hugo

texts.es:
Víctor Hugo is 24, single without children, lives with his parents and is one of 9 children in the family. He started working at an early age. When he was only ten years old he sold natural herb remedies in the street and then started working as a salesman in a shop. And so as a natural businessman he started to save some money to start his own business.

With the limited but valuable money that he was able to save through much sacrifice, he took the first step and bought his first goods to sell. He was then able to become independent by renting a stall in the local market, almost right next to where he used to work, where he now sells embroidered bedspreads, blankets, local clothing and hammocks.

His business started to be profitable and he knew how to advantage of his success. He expanded his store and started to take out loans that he paid back on time.

Having passed a critical stage in his business and realizing that his business could not continue to grow where it was, he decided to close his store to look for new opportunities in order to increase his market. He then began a style of business that is well known in his area, called ‘macate’ (traveling sales on credit from house to house) selling the same products that he sold in his previous business. He started to travel to other richer cities and was able to build a larger clientele so that his business now expands more every day.

Thanks to his efforts he has already bought a motorcycle that he uses as a key element in his work. Víctor hopes to obtain a new loan with which he will buy more wholesale cotton thread in different colors to make bedspreads. He will then give this thread to his family and other people who he will pay to make bedspreads, starting a chain reaction of development in his family and his neighborhood.

Translated from Spanish by Alexandra Jaffe, Kiva volunteer.

Víctor Hugo; tiene 24 años de edad, es soltero y sin hijos, vive con sus padres y es uno de los 9 hijos de esta familia. Desde muy temprano se inició en la vida laboral, ya que a los diez años ya vendía remedios yuyos (hierbas naturales) por las calles y luego entró a trabajar en una mercería como vendedor; y así con su espíritu innato de emprendedor empezó a ahorrar un poco de dinero para poder iniciar su propio negocio.

Con el poco pero muy valioso dinero que con tanto sacrificio había juntado, dio el primer paso, compró con eso las primeras mercaderías con las que logro independizarse alquilando un puesto de venta en el mercado municipal prácticamente al lado de donde estuvo trabajando, vendiendo allí todo tipo de colchas de hilo bordado, frazadas, ropas típicas y hamacas.

Comenzó a dar frutos su emprendimiento, Y lo supo aprovechar, creció su negocio y se animó a tomar sus primeros créditos que los cumplió con pagos excelentes.

Habiendo pasado una etapa crítica y dándose cuenta que en el mismo local ya no era posible seguir creciendo, decidió cerrar su negocio para buscar nuevos horizontes y así ampliar su mercado, llegando a adoptar un estilo de negocio muy conocido en la zona que es el macate (venta ambulante y a crédito casa por casa), vendiendo los mismos productos que vendía en su negocio anterior. Empezó a viajar por otras ciudades con grandes bolsones llenos de mercaderías llegando a conquistar una excelente clientela que hoy día hace que el negocio progrese cada día más.

Gracias a su esfuerzo ya compró una motocicleta que la utiliza como una herramienta importante de trabajo. Víctor desea solicitar un nuevo crédito con el que desea comprar hilos de algodón de diferentes colores y al por mayor para la fabricación de colchas, estos materiales él los entregará a su familia y a otras personas a quienes él paga por la confección de sus colchas creando toda una cadena de desarrollo en su familia y en su barrio.

loans.use: To purchase wholesale cotton thread in different colors

loans.name: Floridalma

texts.en:
Floridalma Martínez, 39, has a business selling fresh raw chicken in the local market. Her store "Pollería Mary" is a simple stall with a concrete table, a cutting board, a knife, and the chicken she has prepared for sale. She sells between 75 and 150 pounds of chicken in an average day, buying about about 7 Quetzales per pound and selling at 8 or 8.5 Quetzales per pound, so she can net perhaps 100 Quetzales, or US$13, on an average day. She also does some catalog sales, with products like Avon. She has a nice niche – the women of the town come to buy their chicken and may also order some cosmetics or other products.

Flori's stall is quite dark, and she doesn't have a front to it, just the one table. She really wants to put in her own electric light and put a front on the stall.

Flori is married and has four children. Keeping her kids in school is the motivation for her business. Since the schools require the children to buy uniforms and school supplies, her four kids put a significant strain on the cash flow. They even hope to buy a computer at some point so they don't have to pay so much for computer and internet rental for the kids' studies.

Written by Nancy Lewis, Kiva Fellow

loans.use: Purchase chicken for resale

loans.name: Aracelli Francisca

texts.es:
ARACELLI is 25 years old. She is separated from her husband because he treated her poorly, which leaves her with two children to raise. She is dedicated to selling barbecued chicken ("pollo asado") from her home. She hopes with this loan to improve her business site in such a way that her clients will not only be able to purchase chicken but also be able to dine there. She is a member of the group "Puente (Bridge) 1" along with Rosalía Velasco Salazar (who has a grocery store) and Francisca M. Gallegos (who also sells chicken). These two women will buy merchandise for their shops and a grill for preparing chicken in greater quantities.

Translated from Spanish by Jay Osborne, Kiva volunteer

ARACELI tiene 25 años, se separo de su esposo porque la maltrataba quedándose con dos hijos, se dedica a la venta de pollo asado en su casa, espera con el préstamo acondicionar el lugar de tal manera que además de comprar también lo puedan consumir ahí. Pertenece al grupo Puente 1 junto con doña Rosalía Velasco Salazar (tienda de abarrotes) y Francisca M. Gallegos (venta de pollo). Ellas dos compraran mercadería para su tienda y la otra comprara una parrilla para asar pollos en mayor cantidad.

loans.use: Selling grilled chicken

loans.name: Maria Estela

texts.en:
Maria Estela M., 52, makes a dynamite pineapple licuado, or fruit milkshake. With fresh pineapple juice and a thickener, she mixes up this premier Guatemalan refreshment in her blender. She's been making her fruit shakes for ten years now. Two years ago she took out her first loan with Friendship Bridge and opened her stall in the Mazatenango market. Her business is called "Bello Amanecer", which means "Beautiful Dawn" in Spanish. Her stand is in one of the best locations in town because she gets all the pedestrian traffic coming and going between the bus station and the market.

Maria is single and supports two of her four children. Her daughter helps her with the stand, which they keep open from eight in the morning until eight at night. She just finished paying off her second loan with Friendship Bridge. Her group of women, the "Mujeres El Progreso", paid their loan off with no late payments among the entire group, so part of the last payment was forgiven them as a bonus. Before starting up with the Friendship Bridge group, Maria had occasionally used bank loans, but they were far more expensive and became cost-prohibitive.

Maria works long hours and has been in good health, but recently she has been losing weight due to an unknown medical problem.

With this loan she will buy more produce to serve the business. Her biggest commitment remains to be educating her children, who are now getting to the end of their educational careers, but who are all pursuing advanced education.

Written by Nancy Lewis, Kiva Fellow

loans.use: Purchase fruits and other raw materials for fruit milkshakes

loans.name: Manuela

texts.en: Manuela

loans.use: Purchase corn and firewood to make tamales

loans.name: Rocelia

texts.es:
ROCELIA is 34 years old, married, and has seven children. Her husband does social work helping people in his community who don't have an education and consequently are mistreated. She is dedicated to making and selling dishes of little pastries that are ordered and delivered from house to house. She is a member of the group "Puente (Bridge) 2" along with doña Maria de Jesús Camacho Hernández (who has a grocery shop), Marcela Núñez Cruz (who sells perfumes and cosmetics), Sara Gómez Espinosa (who sells perfumes), and Antonia Espinosa Torres (who sells fruits and vegetables at the market). With the loan, they all hope to increase their business by buying the merchandise that they need.

Translated from Spanish by Jay Osborne, Kiva volunteer

ROCELIA tiene 34 años, casada, 7 hijos, su esposo trabaja realizando ayudas sociales a la gente de su comunidad que no tienen estudios y que por este motivo abusan de ellos. Ella se dedica a confeccionar y vender pastelitos de manjar a pedido y de casa en casa. Pertenece al grupo puente 2 junto con doña Maria de Jesús Camacho Hernández (tienda de abarrotes), Marcela Núñez Cruz (venta de perfumes y cosméticos), Sara Gómez Espinosa (venta de perfumes), Antonia Espinosa Torres (venta de frutas y verduras en el mercado). Con el préstamo todas esperan incrementar sus negocios comprando más mercancía para abastecerlos.

loans.use: Selling pastries

loans.name: Diega

texts.en:
Diega M., 48, and her husband Juliano have a small grocery store on a back street of their town. They have used previous loans to expand their inventory little by little, and now have the store stocked much better than in the past. This loan will again go to expand inventory.

This will be Diega's second loan with Friendship Bridge; she's a member of the group of women "Sololá". Her goal is to provide for her family. Of their nine children, six still live at home and all are in school, which is an admirable statistic, but requires much cash to support. Her older three children did not go to school, and Diega herself had no schooling whatsoever. She speaks only her first language, Cakchiquel and very little Spanish, and does not read or write.

Diega hopes to expand their house sometime in the future, because there's scarcely room for the six children and nine grandchildren who are often at home.

loans.use: Expand inventory for her store

loans.name: Rosa  Ysela

texts.es:
ROSA YSELA is 44 years old, married, and has four children. Her husband works in the fields as a farmer. She makes traditional meals and breads in her home and sells them from home. She is a member of the group Brasilia 2 along with doña Gladis Ramírez López (who sells perfumes and cosmetics) and Pradería Hernández Saldaña (who has a grocery store). With the loan, Gladis will buy more products and Pradería will increase the amount of food products available at her store. Rosa will design a place in her home for selling her meals.

Translated from Spanish by Jay Osborne, Kiva volunteer

ROSA YSELA, tiene 44 años, casada, cuatro hijos, su esposo trabaja en el campo como agricultor. Ella en su casa hace comida tradicional y pan y lo vende repartiéndolas a domicilio. Pertenece al grupo Brasilia 2 junto con doña Gladis Ramírez López (venta de perfumes y cosméticos) y Pradería Hernández Saldaña (tienda de abarrotes). Con el préstamo Gladis comprara más productos y Pradelia aumentara la mercancía de productos comestibles, Rosa acondicionara un lugar en su hogar para la venta de comida.

loans.use: Selling traditional food

loans.name: Maria Cristina

texts.es:
MARIA CRISTINA is 28 years old, married, and has three children. Her husband works on the farm. She is dedicated to purchasing chickens, which she prepares and separates to sell them among the people of her community. She is a member of the group Brasilia 2, along with doña Rosa Corzo Coutiño (who prepares typical foods). With the loan doña Maria Cristina will buy more live chickens to raise them at her home and from there provide herself with chickens to later sell after they are prepared and quartered. Doña Rosa will buy cooking utensils to increase the preparation of typical foods at her place.

Translated from Spanish by Jay Osborne, Kiva volunteer

MARIA CRISTINA, tiene 28 años, casada, tres hijos, su esposo trabaja en el campo. Ella se dedica a la compra de pollos los cuales prepara y troza para venderlos entre la gente de su comunidad. Pertenece al grupo Brasilia 2, junto con doña Rosa Corzo Coutiño (prepara comida típica). Con el préstamo doña Maria Cristina comprara mas pollos vivos para criarlos en su casa y de ahí abastecerse para posteriormente venderlos destazados y doña Rosa comprara utensilios de cocina para aumentar la preparación de alimentos típicos de su localidad.

loans.use: chicken sales

loans.name: Angélica María

texts.en:
Angelica Maria Vasquez is 35 and runs the small sandal store "Variedades La Promesa". She started the business about six months ago with her sister. They have just a little stall in the center of town, but the stall is well stocked. They used to work for someone else, but they learned the business and decided to strike out on their own. They try to keep their pulse on the fashion trends, making sure they don't get stuck with old styles and can meet the needs of their customers.

Angelica is a member of the group "Mujeres D. Ánimo" and will use this loan to purchase more sandals for sale. In the past she was a member of another women's credit group, but the interest rates and payments were too high, so she's happy to be working with Friendship Bridge now.

She and her husband and two children still live with her father. Of course one of her dreams is to have a house of her own. She would also like to purchase a stove and sell hamburgers and tacos in the space outsiD. their shoe store.

Written by Randy Fay, Kiva Fellow

loans.use: Purchase sandals to increase inventory

loans.name: Maria Del Carmen

texts.es:
Maria del Carmen is twenty-one. She is single. She sells fruits and vegetables door to door. She would use the loan to turn part of her house into a store where she could display produce for sale. She belongs to the group San Vicente 2, along with Olga Margarita Jiménez Hernández, who also sells fruits and vegetables. Olga would use her part of the loan to buy a refrigerated display case for her vegetables

Translated from Spanish by Antonio Padial, Kiva Volunteer

MARIA DEL CARMEN, soltera con 21 años. Ella se dedica al venta de frutas y verduras de manera ambulante de casa en casa, con el préstamo quiere colocar un pequeño local en su casa para exhibir sus producto. Pertenece al grupo San Vicente 2 junto con doña Olga Margarita Jiménez Hernández (venta de frutas y verduras). Ella con su parte del préstamo comprara un conservador de verduras.

loans.use: To buy equipment for a business selling fruits and vegetables

loans.name: Delina

texts.es:
Delina is twenty-two and single. She sells perfumes, cosmetics, and home furnishings. With her earnings, she helps her parents meet household expenses. She would use the loan to buy more inventory, increase her earnings, and continue her studies. She belongs to the group San Vicente 1, along with Rosa Jiménez Hernández (who sells clothing). Rosa would use her part of the loan to travel to the border to stock supplies, so that she could avoid further trips.

Translated from Spanish by Antonio Padial, Kiva Volunteer

DELINA, tiene 22 años, soltera, se dedica a la venta de productos de perfumería, cosméticos, artículos para el hogar, con sus ganancias apoya a sus padres en el mantenimiento del hogar y espera con el préstamo comprar mas mercadería para aumentar sus ganancias y de esta manera continuar con sus estudios. Pertenece al grupo San Vicente 1 junto con Rosa Jiménez Hernández (venta de ropa) con su parte del préstamo viajara a la frontera abastecerse de mercadería para evitar mas viajes

loans.use: To buy supplies for a cosmetics business

loans.name: Julia

texts.en:
Julia P. Y., 36, is a member of a group of women who make and sell traditional handicrafts, including weaving and jewelry. They make the goods in their homes near Sololá and then periodically take the two-hour bus ride to Quetzaltenango to sell to foreigners in the Spanish language schools there. They also give weaving classes in the schools and keep a small consignment operation stocked.

Julia speaks Cakchiquel as her first language, but also speaks Spanish. She is a leader in her community, organizing the women and seeking out effective financing. Her women's group, the "Mujeres Analizadoras", used to get its credit from another organization, but they have switched to Friendship Bridge because they can get a better interest rate. They’re currently in their first loan cycle with Friendship Bridge and will use the credit to buy materials for their work.

A typical item such as a high-quality woven sofa pillowcase that Julia makes will take about 15 days and will bring about 300 Quetzales, or US$40. It’s currently the high season for their sales, because the language students are currently in the schools, so the women are working many hours per day to make their products.

Unlike many of the women in Guatemala, Julia has fifteen years of education, and completed her full high school degree. Over the long term she wants to try to develop new markets, including possible foreign markets, for their handicrafts.

The women are hoping to be able eventually to pool their purchases of thread so they can get a better price with collaborative buying.

loans.use: Buy materials for  weaving and embroidery

loans.name: Martha

texts.es:
Martha is thirty-four. She is married and has three children. Her husband works in the fields. She helps meet household expenses by selling shredded chicken dishes from her home. She belongs to the group San Vicente 2, along with Rosa Santiz Jiménez (grocery store) and Maridalia Jiménez Rodríguez (grocery store). They would use the loan to buy inventory to stock their grocery stores. Martha would buy kitchen utensils and condiments used in the preparation of her chicken dishes.

Translated from Spanish by Antonio Padial, Kiva Volunteer

MARTHA, tiene 34 años, casada, tres hijos, su esposo trabaja en el campo, ella colabora en el hogar vendiendo pollo destrozado. Pertenece al grupo San Vicente 2 junto con doña Rosa Santiz Jiménez (tienda de abarrotes) y Maridalia Jiménez Rodríguez (tienda de abarrotes). Con el préstamo esperan invertir comprando mercaderías para abastecer sus tiendas y Martha comprara implementos de cocina y condimentos para la preparación de sus pollos.

loans.use: To stock a grocery store and buy kitchen utensils

loans.name: Angelina

texts.en:
Angelina C. R., 52, owns and operates a shoe store called "Zapatería Dama Ris". She has been in the shoe business for 33 years. Currently she specializes in traditional sandals. She has been separated from her husband for many years and has three children.

Angelina will use her loan to purchase inventory for her store. Before using loans from Friendship Bridge, she sometimes accessed credit from a bank, but the interest rate was much too high. Now with interest at a more reasonable level she can net a bit more profit to ensure that her youngest child, a 12-year-old, can continue with a full education.

Written by Nancy Lewis, Kiva Fellow

loans.use: Purchase shoe inventory for the store

loans.name: Antonieta

texts.es:
Antonieta is fifty-three. She is divorced and has seven children. She meets household expenses by breeding and raising pigs. She belongs to the group Limonar 6. Her partner in the group also raises and sells pigs. Both would use the loan to buy more livestock and animal feed. They would also use the loan for vaccinations, so that the pigs will not become sick.

Translated from Spanish by Antonio Padial, Kiva Volunteer

ANTONIETA, tiene 53 años, separada con siete hijos, mantiene su hogar con la crianza y engorda de puercos. Pertenece al grupo Limonar 6 junto con doña Antonieta R. León (venta y crianza de puercos). Ambas esperan con el préstamo comprar más animales, alimentos y vacunas para evitar las enfermedades.

loans.use: To buy more stock for her pig farming business

loans.name: Eleacer

texts.es:
Eleacer is forty-two. She is married and has two children. Her husband works in the fields. She belongs to the group Limonar 6 along with Grafira Gordillo Vázquez. Both raise farm animals (pigs and chickens). They would use the loan to buy piglets and chicks, which they would raise and sell when grown for a better profit.

Translated from Spanish by Antonio Padial, Kiva Volunteer

ELEACER, tiene 42 años, casada, dos hijos, su esposo trabaja en el campo. Pertenece al grupo Limonar 6 junto con doña Grafira Gordillo Vázquez, ambas se dedican a la crianza de animales (puercos y pollos). Con el préstamo esperan comprar mas lechoncitos y pollitos para empezar desde pequeños su engorda y obtener mas ganancias ya que el costo de ellos es menor comparado con un animal ya grande.

loans.use: To buy livestock

loans.name: Carmen

texts.es:
Carmen is thirty-five. She is married and has two children. Her husband works in the fields, in the cultivation of sugar cane. She raises pigs. She belongs to the group Limonar 7. Other members of the group are Dolores Cruz Velasco and Amada Gutiérrez Ruiz (who also raise pigs) and Dolores Velasco Avendaño (who sells vegetables). They would use the loan to buy piglets to raise and sell when grown, thereby increasing their profits. Dolores Velasco would invest in a refrigerator to keep her vegetables in good condition for a longer time.

Translated from Spanish by Antonio Padial, Kiva Volunteer

CARMEN tiene 35 años, casada, dos hijos, su esposo trabaja en el campo en el cultivo de la caña. Ella se dedica a la crianza de puercos. Pertenece al grupo Limonar 7. las otras integrantes del grupo son: Dolores Cruz Velasco y Amada Gutiérrez Ruiz ambas se dedican a la crianza de puercos y doña Dolores Velasco Avendaño a la venta de verduras. Con el préstamo esperan invertir en animales pequeños para su engordamiento y de esta forma aumentar sus ganancias, y doña Dolores Velasco espera invertir en un conservador y así mantener en buen estado y mas tiempo sus verduras.

loans.use: To buy livestock and a refrigerator for vegetables

loans.name: Magdalena

texts.en:
Magdalena is a weaver, making both small postcards for tourists and also larger pieces of woven cloth. She's 32 years old and this will be her eighth consecutive loan over four years. She works with her husband Miguel, who packages the postcards. They are successfully supporting their five children, including the oldest, who is a special-needs child.

Magdalena has grown her business substantially through careful investment of her previous credits, and now has quite a stock of woven items and postcards. She now sells from a stall which she rents from the town for about US$4.00/month. She carefully calculates her prices based on the cost of materials, the time required to make the products, and the profit she needs to make from each item.


With the proceeds from this credit she plans to invest in more materials to create products for her small stall in the town.


Magdalena and Miguel own their own house, which is rustic but serviceable. After many years in a much smaller, much poorer house, they used the proceeds from their business to build a much better house out of concrete block, with a good roof.


Magdalena is a member of a group of 30 women called "Catalina". All of her children but the oldest are in school and doing well there, although Magdalena herself had never been to school at all until she married. At that time she took one year of primary school and learned to read and write and a bit of Spanish, all of which have profited her well. (Her first language is not Spanish but rather the Cachiquel language spoken near Lake Atitlan.)


To date the family’s health has been excellent, except that of course the eldest child has ongoing health challenges. Aside from the medicines they have to buy for the eldest, their medical needs have been minimal.

loans.use: she plans to invest in more materials to create products for her small stall

loans.name: Maricruz

texts.en:
Maricruz L., 37, sells new children's clothes and bedding from her house, on the street and to order. Though she is married and her husband works, he does not earn enough to make ends meet. She started her business eight years ago and continues selling the clothes, bedding, and also shoes. She buys new clothes in Guatemala City and then sells the merchandise in the lowland town of Mazatenango.

Maricruz will use the loan she is presently requesting to purchase inventory, since her stock is currently quite low. Eventually she'd like to open a store to sell this same merchandise, but in larger volume. Maricruz is a member of the women's group "Mujeres D. Ánimo", which is now on its third loan with Friendship Bridge. She has three children in school, and school requirements continually eat up her earnings.

loans.use: Purchase more clothing and bedding inventory

loans.name: Maria

texts.en:
Maria C. A., 40, makes tablecloths, bedspreads, and other large woven items from her home. Three other women also weave with her. She's a member of the group of women "Caseria Cooperativa".

A typical piece that she makes costs about Q100, or US$13, and will fetch Q150, or US$20 on the market; it takes one week's labor to make. Maria makes the trip to another city every weekend to sell the items they produce at two stalls in the town.

Without the loans she would not be able to do business. It's important to be able to buy the raw materials in order to have adequate inventory. Maria has her own house, but has no land of her own. She has five children and is married to husband Juan, who has had lung problems for the last ten years and has been unable to work.

loans.use: to buy the raw materials in order to have adequate inventory for weaving

loans.name: Roxanda

texts.en: Roxanda V. M., or "Rossy" as she is known in the neighborhood, buys and sells new and used clothing in her area. She goes to Guatemala City to purchase clothing at wholesale and then brings it back to Mazatenango where she can sell it at a markup. The new clothing will often fetch a 100% markup, while the used clothing does not do so well. She's considering dropping the used clothing line because of the low markup. Rossy is a member of the group of women "Mujeres de Ánimo" and with this loan she'll invest in more new clothing for sale. She thinks she can get at least three dozen pants, three dozen blouses, and two dozen dresses with this credit. Her group is in their third cycle of credit. Rossy dreams of having her own place, instead of having to rent her current apartment, which costs about 700 Guatemalan Quetzales per month, or US$91. And someday she'd like to have a real storefront instead of just having a little room in front of her house. Rossy is unmarried and has two children, but they're now grown.

loans.use: Purchase clothing to add to inventory

loans.name: Brenda

texts.en:
Brenda Nohemí P., 24, runs a typing school, using old-fashioned typewriters. Hers is one of three typing schools in the town, but all the children need to learn how to type before they enter junior high school, so the school has thrived. Brenda and her husband started the school in 2004 after months of bureaucratic paperwork, and launched it with lots of advertising, and the business thrived from the start. 
Brenda charges about US$4.00/month for students to study at the school, and they can finish with certificates of varying ability. Right now she has 150 students studying. 
Like many women in her town, Brenda also has other irons in the fire. On weekends she sells new clothes in the town's Sunday market. Her husband Saulo works as a health worker for a government health service. Both of them are still pursuing advanced education. Brenda is getting a secretarial degree and hopes to go on to university and Saulo is studying Business Administration. They want the best for their two children. And their 5-year-old says he wants to be a doctor, so they're ready to educate him for a long time. Written by Randy Fay, Kiva Fellow

loans.use: Expansion of weekend clothing sales inventory

loans.name: Maria Elena

texts.en:
Maria Elena is 25 years old, single with no children. She makes and sells intricate beadwork and weaving. Her group of women sells to foreign students at the Spanish language schools in Quetzaltenango, about a two-hour bus ride away. The group of women she belongs to is called "Mujeres Analizadoras".
A sample beadwork bag that she makes will fetch Q250, or US$32, but requires two weeks to make, and the material costs about 70 Guatemalan Quetzales, or US$10.
Maria Elena completed her high school education as an adult because she had to stop school at age 10 when her father died. However, by going to a special weekend program she was able to finish her entire degree. She dreams of helping other women to succeed in their business, especially by expanding into new markets. She was the recipient of a 6-month special scholarship for indigenous women leaders to study human rights in Guatemala.

loans.use: Purchase material for making intricate beadwork and weaving traditional Mayan clothes

loans.name: Celestina

texts.en: Celestina is only 26 but has been running her thriving "Ropa Americana" or used American clothing store already for eight years. She buys the clothes in bales from a supplier in Quetzaltenango and brings them to the market here in Chicacao for sale. She even has two employees who work the streets in surrounding towns. She also has a sewing machine and sews blouses and skirts to sell to others. Celestina will use this credit to buy at least 3 bales of US used apparel, which could sell out in just twenty days.  In the distant past she did try using bank credit, but it was too expensive to maintain. Celestina is single. She finished grade 6 but has ambitious plans for her business. She's also helping support her sister, who is just getting back on her feet after losing her husband to an illness.

loans.use: Purchase bales of used American clothing for resale

loans.name: Vidalia

texts.en: Vidalia P. A., 26, weaves and sells traditional fabric handicraft items. She's a member of a group of women that collaboratively sell their goods to Spanish language schools for foreigners in Quetzaltenango, which is about a 2-hour bus ride away. Vidalia is in her first credit cycle with Friendship Bridge, but her group used another credit provider (at a higher interest rate) in the past. Vidalia is married to husband Felipe and has a 9-month-old daughter, but they still live with her father. She had six years of schooling and speaks Spanish in addition to her first language, Cakchiquel.  She has a small plot of land, or milpa, on which she can grow corn, but it doesn't suffice for the family. Her dream is to build her own house and provide successfully for her children's education, so that her kids don't have to suffer through some of the things she's had to endure.

loans.use: to purchase yarn and other material to continue working

loans.name: Etelvina

texts.en: Etevina A. T., 31, sells construction and firewood which seems unusual for a woman in Guatemala but yet her business is thriving. Her business “Venta de Madera  Leonardo¨ inamed after her youngest child is thriving. The demand for new construction wood in her small town is high and she sells all she can buy. When she receives a shipment it is all gone in two weeks.  Next to her home you can find her modest supply of wood post, construction lumber, 2x2 4x4, wood blanks as well as  fire wood. She started this business 5 years ago with the help of her father. She has used traditional banks in the past but they require a co-signer and charge higher rates. Accessing credit through Friendship Bridge is better for her because they do not require a co-signer or collateral and the lower rates means she has more money to reinvest in her business. She is in her 9th cycle of credit with Friendship Bridge, having been successful in repaying loans for more than four years, ever since the program started in her village. Etevina had her own home until her mother got sick and required hospitalization for just a couple of days before her death. Etelvina sold her home to help pay the hospital bill and moved in with her sister, where she and her two children currently live. She did buy a very small house recently but there is not enough room for her family. She will remodel the house so there is enough room for herself and her two children who are 8 and 10 when there is enough money to afford this project.  Etevina has a 6th grade education and values education as a priority in her life. She is very proud that her children have not missed any schooling due to her poverty. As a single parent she struggles to afford school for her children because of the cost of required uniforms, books, paper and pens. Her own dream is to go to nursing school which will cost about US$35 a month for two years. Meanwhile she still needs to provide for her family so she continues to grow her business so she can realize her dreams . Written by Nancy Lewis, Kiva Fellow

loans.use: Purchase additional lumber inventory

loans.name: Juana

texts.en: Juana Sucuquí T., 31, has run her little store for three years. She sells various food items and also new clothes.  She has a refrigerator for cold drinks and a freezer for ice cream and meats. Before she got her first loan and started the store, she worked as a laborer on a farm.  Her husband also sells new clothing and music CDs in the street. Juana has already completed nine six-month loans successfully. She'll invest this loan in new clothes for sale. Juana and her husband have their own house, and her mother lives in back. Her dreams are simple: she wants to see her three children prosper. They're 10, 6, and 1 year old, and the two older kids are doing well in school.

loans.use: Purchase additional clothes to add to inventory.

loans.name: Ana

texts.en: Ana is a weaver, making traditional Mayan clothes for women of her village. The special women’s top she weaves is called a huipil, the most important part of the Maya woman's outfit.  The weave, design and style of each huipil is indicative of the village it is from and is worn with great pride. Ana has no formal education and speaks only Cakchiquel, but is a master weaver with great knowledge of this ancient Guatemalan art. The women’s credit group she belongs to is called “Quetzal”, which is also the name of the currency used in Guatemala.  She has taken out 3 loans in the past year and a half, and she has successfully  repaid each loan.. With this new loan she will purchase new thread and materials to continue weaving.Ana is 40 years old and married. Her husband works as a night watchman  in a nearby town. Together they have raised 4 children, own their own home,  and are now helping raise their five grandchildren. Her goals are simple: to be able to buy more material to weave more and sell the resulting products.  The two or three huipiles she can make and sell in one year will help to support her 5 grandchildren. In her one room home, Ana weaves in the corner and is surrounded by a dozen family members who demonstrate their love for her. The children hang on to her, giving her hugs and thanks for being the special caring person she is.

loans.use: With this loan she will purchase new thread and materials to continue weaving.

loans.name: Maria

texts.en: Maria Buron T. is 37 and runs a little store, the "Tienda Nueva" or "New Store". She has had the store for fifteen years and has grown it into a respectable little neighborhood resource. Maria never went to school and only speaks a little Spanish but she runs the store and also sells in the town center on market day. The family is always figuring out another way to make a few quetzals. She's in her first credit cycle with Friendship Bridge and is a member of the women's group "Puente de Amistad". The loan will be used as working capital to buy more products for the store and to sell in the Sunday market. Maria has great hopes for her five children. All of them have prospered in school and she's hoping they'll have distinguished careers involving good houses and professions, and that maybe they'll have computers. In the past four years she has had some significant back problems, and despite many visits to specialists, she's had no relief. Written by Randy Fay, Kiva Fellow

loans.use: Purchase inventory for store

loans.name: Catarina

texts.en:
Catarina O. P., 45, supports herself by weaving huipiles, the traditional blouse worn by Mayan women. She will use the proceeds of this credit to buy more material. It can take a full month of full time work to make one huipil, and the material normally costs about 75 quetzals, or US$10, but she can sell the finished huipil for about 500 quetzales, or US$65.  She sells her work in the street, and also sells to tourists in a nearby town. She also sells small bags of a nut called “aba” for 1 quetzal each (about US$0.08)  and helps in her sister’s  tortilla business. Catarina is separated from her husband, who drank and beat her. She has a total of 7 children ranging in age from 7 to 25. The four younger children live with her. While she is building her own home, they are all  living with a  friend. The house is almost complete, but needs windows and a few other finish items before they move in. 
It has been a long struggle for Catarina but she is persistent. She never had any schooling and speaks only the Cakchiquel language.  Her long-term dream is to be able to open a fruit stand and sell bananas, papaya, apples, pineapples, oranges, and other local fruits. Before receiving micro credits Catarina  had no way to support herself, but now she is on her sixth loan in three years, and she has successfully paid off all previous loans. She says that before receiving the credits she had absolutely no cash and no way to support her family, but as her business has developed she’s very proud of her ability to take care of her children. Perhaps as she is able to continue her success the sadness she feels concerning her family situation and estranged husband will diminish over time.

loans.use: She will use the proceeds of this credit to buy more material

loans.name: Petrona

texts.en: Petrona M. C. is 28 and earns her living by buying new clothes in the  nearest major city and selling them in the local market in her small town. In December when the workers return from the United States to see their family she also buys and sells fruit, since there are many people in the town with money to spend. She knows that the many people returning home miss the wonderful fresh fruits grown in the fertile lands of Guatemala. She will use this loan to buy inventory to restock her stall in the lowlands of Guatemala. Early this year Petrona's husband died after an 8-month-long serious illness during which he could not work. She somehow managed to take care of him and their 5 young children. It has been a very hard struggle. At the end of the day she has very little energy left  after tending her business and taking care of her children. The older three are in school for now but she worries she can not afford the cost of schooling for all five. They wear used clothes or "American clothing", hand-me-downs from the US sold here in the markets, but they are clean and well mended. She does the best she can with the help of her sister and her strong faith.  She also gets emotional support from her Friendship Bridge women’s group named "Luz en el Desierto" or  “light in the desert” Currently Petrona's dream is to make it through another day and heal from recent the death of her young husband. She has says she has to fight the fight for the kids. She is putting her life back together bit by bit. The help from Friendship Bridge is essential to her survival.

loans.use: Purchase clothing to add to inventory

loans.name: Carmen

texts.en: Carmen M. S., 29,  has now completed three credit cycles with Friendship Bridge. With the first credit, she bought a single piglet, and now she has four that are getting close to being ready for market. They each take 5-8 months to raise to maturity, although some grow faster than others. She buys waste tortillas to feed them. A single piglet costs about US$20 when young and will fetch between $65 and $80 when mature. Carmen hopes to buy at least one more piglet with this coming credit, and to continue feeding the others until they're ready for market. Carmen did not have any schooling, and never learned to read or write. But she's making sure that her three children will be able to go to school. The oldest, age 7, is already ahead of her because he's learning to read in the first grade. And she's very proud of him.

loans.use: Purchase and feed additional pigs

loans.name: Dolores

texts.en:
Dolores Lopes Matin weaves Mayan textiles for belts, collars, purses and postcards, and she also makes custom jewelry to sell to tourists.  She knows her business and how to prepare for the seasonal fluctuations and other challenges that come her way. 
Dolores was born 50 years ago and still lives in the same house where her family has always lived.  She sits on the earthen floor on a piece of cardboard weaving a bright yellow and very long narrow fabric which will be cut up to make postcards. She had never had her own stall or store to sell her crafts but does her work to order for others who will then sell on the street or in their stalls.This very demure woman looks frail, but she has a heart and smile as big as the world. After Hurricane Stan destroyed a local church, she opened her home to those that needed a new place to worship and recover from the devastation. The fact that the worshipers are of a different denomination than she is makes no difference to her.  Although Dolores is single and has no children, she opens her heart and home for those in need.  She also shares her home as a sanctuary for a friend whose husband drank too much and beat her but remains responsible for raising and supporting 6 children. 
Dolores started out her business with a little money from her father to buy material. But when someone stole everything she had, she started using credit to buy materials to jump start her business. She is now a member of the women’s group called “Shalom” where she has been an outstanding member for 4 years. She will use this loan to buy more material to make more weaving which she sells to other women.

loans.use: She will use this loan to buy more material to make more weavings which she sells to other women.

loans.name: Elena

texts.en:
Elena Coché P., 30, and her husband Gaspar have a small, struggling business as clothing sellers on the street. They buy just 15 dozen new clothing items at a time and sell them on the street and at Gaspar's small stall in a nearby town. They can buy a dozen blouses for about US$19 and then sell them for a net profit of about $4.60 a dozen. This credit is then used to buy another few dozen blouses.

Neither Elena nor Gaspar had any schooling, but of their four children the two eldest are already in school, and the younger two are not yet old enough. They're committed to helping the children have a better life than they have had. Their biggest challenges, besides just making ends meet and paying the monthly school fees, are with health. They live along a little creek that is also their water source, and during the rainy season it seems to be more contaminated and the kids have more illnesses. Even the purchase of a few pills for the kids is a strain on their budget.

Elena is a member of the women's group "Mas Que Vencedoras", which means "More than Conquerors".

loans.use: Purchase additional clothes for resale

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en:
Erlinda G., 41, and her daughter Sonia, 16, have a little side business of selling cosmetics and soap products to neighbors and friends. Sonia is only 16, but has already grown the business to the point of making a profit of as much as US$140 per month. Many times when the family comes up short on the monthly payment for the other kids' schooling, Sonia comes through with a bit of money to make up the difference.

Erlinda has been borrowing with Friendship Bridge credits for four years now, and is requesting a relatively small loan this time, which will be used to invest in more products for Sonia's cosmetics sales.

Erlinda has two boys in school and they're doing well. She herself had no schooling at all, although she can read a bit and write a little. She's committed to the education of the boys, and hopes they'll have better careers as a result.

loans.use: Purchase inventory for cosmetics sales

loans.name: Ramos

texts.en:
For the last 12 years, Ramos C. has been weaving and selling her Mayan handicrafts in a village along the shore of Lake Atitlan in the Highlands of Guatemala. You can find this shy woman weaving a belt or a tablecloth every day at a stall along the road, which leads to and from the docks at the lake. She works hard in order to take care of her ten children, aged 3 to 23. At the age of 42, she and her husband dream of earning enough to feed, clothe and educate all ten of their children. She never had an educational opportunity and speaks mostly the local Mayan language, Cachiquel.

Ramos will be starting her ninth credit, with more than four years of successful repayment history. The credit she is requesting in this cycle will be used to buy materials and also to pay for some of the school expenses of her children.

The closest she has come to receiving an education is at the monthly meetings of her women’s credit group called “Santa Caterina”. Here she learns about managing a business, health care for herself and her family and gets to talk with other women. Ramos likes the meeting very much, but because of her diminished hearing, it is sometimes hard to understand all that is going on, and sometimes the meeting deals with subjects, which are far from her normal day to day life.

Before she took out her first loan she could only make one product at a time because she had to sell that one in order to buy material for the next. With her small credits she has been able to buy enough material to weave many and sell her hand-woven craft at her own stall along the road, which leads to and from the docks at the lake.

loans.use: The loan is to buy new material to be able to weave more.

loans.name: Daisy

texts.es:
Daisy Noelia J. V. is 26 years old, lives in Pelopincho, Asunción and is an active businesswoman. Starting in the early morning hours she works in her store receiving customers. At first, 7 years ago, the store belonged to her in-laws who transferred it to her so that she could run it and become more independent. Her husband works repairing milking machines. They have three children, 7, 3 and 1 year olds respectively, the eldest now entering his first years of school. They have projects and dreams and are ready to work hard day after day to strengthen their business so that her husband can stop working as a repairman and work with her in the store. They could then expand their business, improve their quality of life and afford better education for their children.

Their store is part of a group of microbusiness, CME Tecojoja, made up of 15 people who are mutually responsible for their loans. Daisy Noelia J. is asking for a loan of $100 to buy merchandise such as sugar, herbs, pasta, oil, flour, drinks, vegetables, fruits, meat and dairy products.

Translated from Spanish by Alexandra Jaffe, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Daisy Noelia J. V., que vive en Pelopincho, Asunción, es una activa emprendedora de 26 años. Desde tempranas horas se dedica a atender su despensa recibiendo a los clientes. Inicialmente, hace 7 años, el negocio pertenecía a sus suegros, quienes les transfirieron para dedicarse a explotarlo e independizarse. Su marido trabaja como repartidor de lácteos en una empresa y tienen tres hijos, de 7, 3 y 1 año respectivamente, el primero ya cursando los primeros grados de la escuela. Tienen proyectos e ilusiones, están dispuestos a esforzarse día a día y fortalecer su negocio para que su marido pueda dejar de ser repartidor de lácteos y junto a ella dedicarse a la despensa y crecer día a día, mejorando su nivel de vida y ofrecerle a sus hijos una mejor educación.

El negocio forma parte de un grupo de microempresas CME “Tecojoja” integrada por 15 personas que responden solidariamente por un préstamo. La Sra. Daisy Noelia J. ha solicitado un préstamo de USD 100, para comprar mercaderías tales como azúcar, yerba, fideos, aceites, panificados, bebidas, verduras, frutas, carne y lácteos.

loans.use: To purchase sugar, herbs, noodles, oil, flour, drinks, vegetables, fruits, meat and dairy products.

loans.name: Francisca

texts.en:
Francisca G., 49, is married and lives with her husband and five children in the lush green lowlands of western Guatemala. She sells chicken and other groceries from her small neighborhood store, the "Tienda Noremí", named after her youngest daughter. She has grown her business over four years from just a few beans and groceries to a pretty significant little store. Her big product is chicken, which she buys and sells about 300 pounds of a week, for a profit of nearly US$60. The loan she is requesting will once again be used to buy more products to sell, including chicken.

Paying the electric bill to run the refrigerator and keeping the kids in school are a running battle. Her husband works in the fields, but at this time of year the harvest is over and he just finds any work that he can do. She is thankful to provide an extra income that makes their ups and downs more manageable.

Francisca cannot read or write, but is very proud that all of her children have the opportunity to get a good education.

loans.use: Purchase inventory for store

loans.name: Francisca Juliana

texts.en:
Francisca Juliana Tale, 46, has been growing her little corner store for 20 years. She started it when her husband broke his leg and injured his spine, and has had it going ever since. She started out with an investment of just 20 Guatemalan Quetzals (maybe US$5.00 at the time) by buying just a few snack items and some tortillas. Through reinvestment of her profits over the years, she's grown it into a business that almost supports the whole family and has a pretty good stock. Some of her best customers are the children who pass by on the way to and from school. She has most things anyone could want for daily use, including snack food and soft drinks, flour, sugar, salt, and a fair selection of pharmacy items that are unusual in a little store like this.

Francisca's husband did eventually return to work, but his back deteriorated and he now does not work outside the store. The store now (almost) supports the family, but the monthly payments for school for the youngest three children are still a bit of a crisis every month. She's hopes with great hope for their schooling and that they'll have a better life than she has had.

Francisca is a member of the women's group "Mujeres Prudentes" and will use this credit, like the previous ones, to finance the purchase of merchandise for the store.

loans.use: Purchase Inventory for store

loans.name: Jesus

texts.en:
Jesus Ixmatá, 33, has several businesses that she is operating with the help of her husband. Currently, her biggest money-maker is selling firewood to her neighbors. She has about 10 cords stacked neatly near her house, and there are 50 more in another location. Her husband cuts the wood at a location about 60 kilometers away and then pays for it to be hauled to the nearest road access. Several men then carry all the wood the mile or so up the path to their house.

Jesus has a number of other endeavors underway, which will eventually pay off. She started a tiny store – hardly more than a couple dozen items of snack food, and she grows a few plants, sells beans, and is raising one pig, which will be ready for market in just a few more months. To feed the pig, she goes door to door to buy waste tortillas from the neighbors. She's hoping the income from the pig will cover the children's schooling and help with her 7-year-old disabled son, who cannot walk, talk or feed himself. He requires special milk and disposable diapers.

Jesus's sights are set on an education for all her children, so they'll have an easier start than she has had. She's a member of the women's group "Mas Que Vencedoras", or "More than conquerors". This credit will go to buy and feed another pig.

loans.use: Purchase more pigs to feed and sell

loans.name: Albino

texts.en:
Albino V. started working as a mechanic at age 16 helping others in their auto repair shops. By 24 years old, after attending a vocational school, he started his own mechanic shop. 

Albino is now 32 years old, a husband and a father of three daughters, age 12, 10, and 5. His wife stays at home to watch over their children. He works six days a week from Monday to Saturday. His hours are usually from 7 am to 6 pm. However, some nights he works as late as 11 pm. 

Albino has many clients that seek his service. He needs a loan of US$300 to buy more equipment to fix cars.

loans.use: Purchase equipment to fix cars.

loans.name: Caterina

texts.en:
Catarina C. P., 45, buys woven clothing to sell to others. Catarina lost her house to Hurricane Stan in October, 2005, so she no longer has her own house. The land swallowed up her house and everything she owned. The recovery has been slow.

Before the hurricane, she used to weave huipiles, colorful Mayan women’s blouses, in her home with a reliable loom. Now she lives in a rented two room house made with concrete block; the old metal window-frames no longer have glass, so she piles up rocks in the window for a bit of privacy. She has a table, an ancient school chair, a mat to sleep on, and a tiny loom she uses to weave cloth bracelets. On the table she displays her complete inventory of eight scarves that she has managed to buy from a friend.

With this loan, Catarina plans to buy 24 chicks and feed them. She will sell them when they are full grown. Until that time, she’ll continue to buy yarn and weave the bracelets that are supporting her and her husband. Her ultimate goal is to build a new home near her son’s home up on the hill in one of the many villages near Lake Atitlan.

Although she can make 100 bracelets a day, she cannot afford medical care. Currently, she has a rotten tooth that gives her great pain and there is not enough extra money to go to the dentist.

loans.use: Purchase chicks to raise
